metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: R Data Frames
Data Frames
Data Frames are data displayed in a format as a table.
content.html: Data Frames are data displayed in a format as a table.

content.text: Data Frames can have different types of data inside it. While the first column can be character , the second and third can be numeric or logical . However, each column should have the same type of data.
content.html: Data Frames can have different types of data inside it. While the first column can be character, the second and third can be numeric or logical. However, each column should have the same type of data.

content.text: Use the data.frame() function to create a data frame:
content.html: Use the data.frame() function to create a data frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
# Create a data frameData_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Print the data frameData_Frame

content.code:
# Create a data frameData_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))# Print the data frameData_Frame

syntax_highlighting.text:
# Create a data frameData_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))# Print the data frameData_Frame

content.code_html:
# Create a data frame
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Print the data frame
Data_Frame

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
# Create a data frameData_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Print the data frameData_Frame

content.text: Summarize the Data
Use the summary() function to summarize the data from a Data Frame:
content.html: Use the summary() function to summarize the data from a Data Frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Framesummary(Data_Frame)

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))Data_Framesummary(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))Data_Framesummary(Data_Frame)

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

Data_Frame

summary(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Framesummary(Data_Frame)

content.text: You will learn more about the summary() function in the statistical part of the R tutorial.
content.html: You will learn more about the summary() function in the statistical part of the R tutorial.

content.text: Access Items
We can use single brackets [ ] , double brackets [[ ]] or $ to access columns from a data frame:
content.html: We can use single brackets [ ], double brackets [[ ]] or $ to access columns from a data frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Frame[1]
  Data_Frame[["Training"]]Data_Frame$Training

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))Data_Frame[1]
Data_Frame[["Training"]]Data_Frame$Training

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))Data_Frame[1]
 Data_Frame[["Training"]]Data_Frame$Training

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

Data_Frame[1]

Data_Frame[["Training"]]

Data_Frame$Training

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Frame[1]
  Data_Frame[["Training"]]Data_Frame$Training

content.text: Add Rows
Use the rbind() function to add new rows in a Data Frame:
content.html: Use the rbind() function to add new rows in a Data Frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Add a new rowNew_row_DF <- rbind(Data_Frame, c("Strength", 
  110, 110))# Print the new rowNew_row_DF

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))# Add a new rowNew_row_DF <- rbind(Data_Frame, c("Strength",
110, 110))# Print the new rowNew_row_DF

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))# Add a new rowNew_row_DF <- rbind(Data_Frame, c("Strength", 
 110, 110))# Print the new rowNew_row_DF

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Add a new row
New_row_DF <- rbind(Data_Frame, c("Strength", 110, 110))

# Print the new row
New_row_DF

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Add a new rowNew_row_DF <- rbind(Data_Frame, c("Strength", 
  110, 110))# Print the new rowNew_row_DF

content.text: Add Columns
Use the cbind() function to add new columns in a Data Frame:
content.html: Use the cbind() function to add new columns in a Data Frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Add a new columnNew_col_DF <- cbind(Data_Frame, Steps = 
  c(1000, 6000, 2000))# Print the new columnNew_col_DF

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))# Add a new columnNew_col_DF <- cbind(Data_Frame, Steps =
c(1000, 6000, 2000))# Print the new columnNew_col_DF

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))# Add a new columnNew_col_DF <- cbind(Data_Frame, Steps = 
  c(1000, 6000, 2000))# Print the new columnNew_col_DF

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Add a new column
New_col_DF <- cbind(Data_Frame, Steps = c(1000, 6000, 2000))

# Print the new column
New_col_DF

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Add a new columnNew_col_DF <- cbind(Data_Frame, Steps = 
  c(1000, 6000, 2000))# Print the new columnNew_col_DF

content.text: Remove Rows and Columns
Use the c() function to remove rows and columns in a Data Frame:
content.html: Use the c() function to remove rows and columns in a Data Frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Remove the first row and columnData_Frame_New <- 
  Data_Frame[-c(1), -c(1)]# Print the new data frameData_Frame_New
# Remove the first row and column

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))# Remove the first row and columnData_Frame_New <-
Data_Frame[-c(1), -c(1)]# Print the new data frameData_Frame_New

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))# Remove the first row and columnData_Frame_New <- 
  Data_Frame[-c(1), -c(1)]# Print the new data frameData_Frame_New
# Remove the first row and column

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Remove the first row and column
Data_Frame_New <- Data_Frame[-c(1), -c(1)]

# Print the new data frame
Data_Frame_New

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))# Remove the first row and columnData_Frame_New <- 
  Data_Frame[-c(1), -c(1)]# Print the new data frameData_Frame_New
# Remove the first row and column

content.text: Amount of Rows and Columns
Use the dim() function to find the amount of rows and columns in a Data Frame:
content.html: Use the dim() function to find the amount of rows and columns in a Data Frame:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))dim(Data_Frame)

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))dim(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))dim(Data_Frame)

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

dim(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))dim(Data_Frame)

content.text: You can also use the ncol() function to find the number of columns and nrow() to find the number of rows:
content.html: You can also use the ncol() function to find the number of columns and nrow() to find the number of rows:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))ncol(Data_Frame)nrow(Data_Frame)

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))ncol(Data_Frame)nrow(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))ncol(Data_Frame)nrow(Data_Frame)

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

ncol(Data_Frame)
nrow(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))ncol(Data_Frame)nrow(Data_Frame)

content.text: Data Frame Length
Use the length() function to find the number of columns in a Data Frame (similar to ncol() ):
content.html: Use the length() function to find the number of columns in a Data Frame (similar to ncol()):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))length(Data_Frame)

content.code:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))length(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))length(Data_Frame)

content.code_html:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

length(Data_Frame)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))length(Data_Frame)

content.text: Combining Data Frames
Use the rbind() function to combine two or more data frames in R vertically:
content.html: Use the rbind() function to combine two or more data frames in R vertically:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame1 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Frame2 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Stamina", 
  "Stamina", "Strength"),  Pulse = c(140, 150, 160),  Duration = 
  c(30, 30, 20))New_Data_Frame <- rbind(Data_Frame1, Data_Frame2)
  New_Data_Frame

content.code:
Data_Frame1 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))Data_Frame2 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Stamina",
"Stamina", "Strength"),  Pulse = c(140, 150, 160),  Duration =
c(30, 30, 20))New_Data_Frame <- rbind(Data_Frame1, Data_Frame2)
New_Data_Frame

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame1 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))Data_Frame2 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Stamina", 
 "Stamina", "Strength"),  Pulse = c(140, 150, 160),  Duration = 
  c(30, 30, 20))New_Data_Frame <- rbind(Data_Frame1, Data_Frame2)
  New_Data_Frame

content.code_html:
Data_Frame1 <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

Data_Frame2 <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Stamina", "Stamina", "Strength"),
  Pulse = c(140, 150, 160),
  Duration = c(30, 30, 20)
)

New_Data_Frame <- rbind(Data_Frame1, Data_Frame2)
New_Data_Frame

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame1 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Frame2 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Stamina", 
  "Stamina", "Strength"),  Pulse = c(140, 150, 160),  Duration = 
  c(30, 30, 20))New_Data_Frame <- rbind(Data_Frame1, Data_Frame2)
  New_Data_Frame

content.text: And use the cbind() function to combine two or more data frames in R horizontally:
content.html: And use the cbind() function to combine two or more data frames in R horizontally:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Frame3 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Frame4 <- data.frame (  Steps = c(3000, 6000, 
  2000),  Calories = c(300, 400, 300))New_Data_Frame1 <- 
  cbind(Data_Frame3, Data_Frame4)New_Data_Frame1

content.code:
Data_Frame3 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina",
"Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30,
45))Data_Frame4 <- data.frame (  Steps = c(3000, 6000,
2000),  Calories = c(300, 400, 300))New_Data_Frame1 <-
cbind(Data_Frame3, Data_Frame4)New_Data_Frame1

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Frame3 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
 "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
 45))Data_Frame4 <- data.frame (  Steps = c(3000, 6000, 
 2000),  Calories = c(300, 400, 300))New_Data_Frame1 <- 
  cbind(Data_Frame3, Data_Frame4)New_Data_Frame1

content.code_html:
Data_Frame3 <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

Data_Frame4 <- data.frame (
  Steps = c(3000, 6000, 2000),
  Calories = c(300, 400, 300)
)

New_Data_Frame1 <- cbind(Data_Frame3, Data_Frame4)
New_Data_Frame1

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Frame3 <- data.frame (  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", 
  "Other"),  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),  Duration = c(60, 30, 
  45))Data_Frame4 <- data.frame (  Steps = c(3000, 6000, 
  2000),  Calories = c(300, 400, 300))New_Data_Frame1 <- 
  cbind(Data_Frame3, Data_Frame4)New_Data_Frame1
